attributes.title: Fork of When Does the Punishment End? The Effects of a Former Criminal Conviction on Employability and Meaning in Life
attributes.description: We examined the effects of a criminal status on society’s perceptions of an individual’s abilities as an employee, character, and meaning in life. This group of studies utilizes the sociological concept of labeling theory to discern the effects of labeling an individual as a criminal based on the presence of a previous criminal conviction on the labeled individual's employment outcomes, as well as societal perceptions and self-perception.

q3.value: Student participants will imagine (and write about) their best possible life, either (A) after college, or (B) after college and with a previous conviction for non-violent crime.  Afterwards, they will provide ratings of their (imagined) meaning in life and attitudes towards "ban the box" legislation, convicts, and ex-convicts.

q4.value:
1. Participants in the criminal condition will report significantly lower (imagined) meaning in life than those in the control condition
2. The facet of meaning which will most strongly mediate the effect described in Hypothesis 1 is (imagined) coherence in life.  Participants in the criminal condition will report significantly lower levels of coherence and this decrease will account for the lower amount of meaning in life reported in this condition.
3. Participants in the criminal condition will be more likely to support national "Ban the Box" legislation and will demonstrate more favorable attitudes towards convicts/ex-convicts.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned between two conditions. In the first condition, participants will write about their best possible life after graduating college. In the second condition, participants will write about their best possible life as someone who recently graduated college but was also recently convicted of a non-violent crime. After writing about their best possible self in this imagined scenario, participants will complete measures of regarding their (imagined) meaning in life (using an adaptation of the measure by Costin & Vignoles, 2019) and attitudes towards criminals/convicts/ex-convicts (using a question regarding endorsement of national "Ban the Box" legislation and the Attitudes toward Convicts and Ex-Convicts scale by Palmer, et al., 1989).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected from introductory psychology students at the University of Missouri, Columbia.  All participants are required to be at least 18 years of age.

q13.value: We hope to recruit a sample of 100-200 participants.

question.value: Imagining oneself as either a recent college graduate (control condition), or a recent college graduate who was also recently convicted of a non-violent crime (criminal condition).

Clarity of the imagined scenario and ease of accessing that scenario.
Meaning in Life, Coherence in Life, Purpose in Life, and Significance in Life as measured by the Multidimensional Meaning in Life Scale (Costin & Vignoles, 2019).
One question regarding endorsement of National "Ban the Box" legislation
Attitudes towards Convicts and Ex-Convicts (Palmer et al., 1989)
Demographic variables (e.g., SES ladder, age, race)

simple means across items (after reverse-coding) will be calculated as indices of the following variables:
Meaning in Life
Coherence in Life
Purpose in Life
Significance in Life
Attitudes towards Convicts and Ex-Convicts
t-tests will be used for simple comparisons between conditions.  Sequential linear regression will be used in the evaluation of our mediational hypothesis.  Manipulation checks will not be used.

q23.value: listwise deletion within scales; pairwise deletion between inferential analyses

attributes.title: Impuls Project
attributes.description: The goal of the current study is to test the correlations of the Three Factor Impulsivity Index with psychopathological symptoms, substance use, personality traits, sleep quality and physical activity behavior, each assessed by gold standard questionnaires. This work will provide a better understanding of underlying constructs of emotion-related impulsivity. A clearer understanding of this trait may help clinicians to create better treatments targeting impulsive symptoms existing in a broad range of psycho-pathologies like bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

attributes.title: Power and Gender
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
•	Sex (self-reported: male, female, other)
•	The meaning of power: Opportunity vs. responsibility (manipulated; 2 conditions)

question2b.value:
•	The meaning of power (opportunity vs. responsibility; 2 scales; Scheepers et al., 2013 BJSP)
•	Propensity to negotiate (1 item; Magee et al., 2007; PSPB)

question3b.value: Masculine and feminine gender identity German Extended Personal Attributes Questionnaire Masculinity/ Femininity Scale (measured continuously by means of the GEPAQ-M/F; Runge et al., 1981)

question10b.value: •	Participants will be recruited through Prolific and then complete the questionnaire as posted on OSF.

question4b.value: Participants need to have a management role in their organization; We need a balanced gender-division.

question5b.value: 200 participants who have a management role in a company/organization will be recruited via Prolific.

question6b.value: Power analysis (power = .80, α = .05) indicated that we need 194 participants to detect the smallest effect found in a pilot study (r = .20).

question7b.value: We will stop data-collection when n=200; excluded participants will be replaced (see below)

question8b.value:
•	A participant will be excluded and replaced with a new participant if they: 
o	Fail both attention checks
o	Fail to complete 25% or more of the questions
o	Complete the entire study in 5 minutes or less, or 25 minutes or more

question1a.value:
1.	Among leaders, a stronger masculine gender identity relates to a stronger tendency to see power as an opportunity
2.	Among leaders, a stronger feminine gender identity relates to a stronger tendency to see power as a responsibility
3.	(Self-identified) males are to a stronger extent inclined to see their power as an opportunity than (self-identified) females
4.	(Self-identified) females are to a stronger extent inclined to see their power as a responsibility than (self-identified) males
5.	Making the opportunities attached to power salient leads to a stronger propensity to negotiate than making the responsibilities attached to power salient
6.	The relationship described in Hypothesis 5 is especially strong among male leaders (interaction)
7.	The relationship described in Hypothesis 5 is especially strong for leaders with a strong masculine gender-identity (interaction)

question2a.value:
When male power-holders reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position, we expect them to have a stronger propensity to negotiate than when female power-holders reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position.

When power-holders with a strong masculine identity reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position, we expect them to have a stronger propensity to negotiate than when power-holders with a weak masculine identity reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position.

question3a.value: We will prime power as opportunity or power as responsibility using a writing exercise. Three coders, blind to condition, will code the written texts in terms of opportunity vs. responsibility.

question1c.value:
•	Based on previous research (Runge et al., 1981; Scheepers et al., 2013) scales will be construed for 1. masculine gender identity, 2. feminine gender identity, 3. the opportunity meaning of power, and 4. the responsibility meaning of power. Items will only be removed from a scale when the Crohnbach’s alpha drops below .70. 
•	Hypothesis 1 will be tested using regression analysis with the masculine gender identity scale and the feminine gender identity scale as predictors and the opportunity meaning of power scale as dependent variable. 
•	Hypothesis 2 will be tested using regression analysis with the masculine gender identity scale and the feminine gender identity scale as predictors and the responsibility meaning of power scale as dependent variable. 
•	Hypothesis 3 will be tested using a t-test with sex (male, female) as independent variable and the opportunity meaning of power scale as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 4 will be tested using a t-test with sex (male, female) as independent variable and the responsibility meaning of power scale as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 5 will be tested using a t-test with prime (opportunity, responsibility) as independent variable and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 5 will be tested using a ANOVA with prime (opportunity, responsibility) and sex (male vs. female) as independent variable and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 6 will be tested using an ANCOVA with prime (opportunity, responsibility) and masculine gender identity (continuous, entered as covariate) as independent variables and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.

question3c.value:
Sex is independent variable
Gender-identity is independent variable (masculine, feminine; 2 scales)
Condition (prime; opportunity vs. responsibility) is independent variable
Meaning of power (opportunity vs. responsibility; 2 scales) is dependent variable
Propensity to negotiate is dependent variable

question4c.value: Gender identity is continuous independent variable. We will include this in the analysis as a covariate, and then also calculate the interaction between gender identity and condition to predict the propensity to negotiate.

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1.	Among leaders, a stronger masculine gender identity relates to a stronger tendency to see power as an opportunity
2.	Among leaders, a stronger feminine gender identity relates to a stronger tendency to see power as a responsibility
3.	(Self-identified) males are to a stronger extent inclined to see their power as an opportunity than (self-identified) females
4.	(Self-identified) females are to a stronger extent inclined to see their power as a responsibility than (self-identified) males
5.	Making the opportunities attached to power salient leads to a stronger propensity to negotiate than making the responsibilities attached to power salient
6.	The relationship described in Hypothesis 5 is especially strong among male leaders (interaction)
7.	The relationship described in Hypothesis 5 is especially strong for leaders with a strong masculine gender-identity (interaction)

When power-holders with a strong masculine identity reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position, we expect them to have a stronger propensity to negotiate than when power-holders with a weak masculine identity reflect on the opportunities attached to their power position.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We will prime power as opportunity or power as responsibility using a writing exercise. Three coders, blind to condition, will code the written texts in terms of opportunity vs. responsibility.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
•	Sex (self-reported: male, female, other)
•	The meaning of power: Opportunity vs. responsibility (manipulated; 2 conditions)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
•	The meaning of power (opportunity vs. responsibility; 2 scales; Scheepers et al., 2013 BJSP)
•	Propensity to negotiate (1 item; Magee et al., 2007; PSPB)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: Masculine and feminine gender identity German Extended Personal Attributes Questionnaire Masculinity/ Femininity Scale (measured continuously by means of the GEPAQ-M/F; Runge et al., 1981)
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: •	Participants will be recruited through Prolific and then complete the questionnaire as posted on OSF.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
•	Based on previous research (Runge et al., 1981; Scheepers et al., 2013) scales will be construed for 1. masculine gender identity, 2. feminine gender identity, 3. the opportunity meaning of power, and 4. the responsibility meaning of power. Items will only be removed from a scale when the Crohnbach’s alpha drops below .70. 
•	Hypothesis 1 will be tested using regression analysis with the masculine gender identity scale and the feminine gender identity scale as predictors and the opportunity meaning of power scale as dependent variable. 
•	Hypothesis 2 will be tested using regression analysis with the masculine gender identity scale and the feminine gender identity scale as predictors and the responsibility meaning of power scale as dependent variable. 
•	Hypothesis 3 will be tested using a t-test with sex (male, female) as independent variable and the opportunity meaning of power scale as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 4 will be tested using a t-test with sex (male, female) as independent variable and the responsibility meaning of power scale as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 5 will be tested using a t-test with prime (opportunity, responsibility) as independent variable and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 5 will be tested using a ANOVA with prime (opportunity, responsibility) and sex (male vs. female) as independent variable and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.
•	Hypothesis 6 will be tested using an ANCOVA with prime (opportunity, responsibility) and masculine gender identity (continuous, entered as covariate) as independent variables and the propensity to negotiate as dependent variable.

Sex is independent variable
Gender-identity is independent variable (masculine, feminine; 2 scales)
Condition (prime; opportunity vs. responsibility) is independent variable
Meaning of power (opportunity vs. responsibility; 2 scales) is dependent variable
Propensity to negotiate is dependent variable

Gender identity is continuous independent variable. We will include this in the analysis as a covariate, and then also calculate the interaction between gender identity and condition to predict the propensity to negotiate.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants need to have a management role in their organization; We need a balanced gender-division.
200 participants who have a management role in a company/organization will be recruited via Prolific.
Power analysis (power = .80, α = .05) indicated that we need 194 participants to detect the smallest effect found in a pilot study (r = .20).
We will stop data-collection when n=200; excluded participants will be replaced (see below)
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
•	A participant will be excluded and replaced with a new participant if they: 
o	Fail both attention checks
o	Fail to complete 25% or more of the questions
o	Complete the entire study in 5 minutes or less, or 25 minutes or more

attributes.title: A Preference for Error-Inducing Price Complexity

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Any contrasts between aforementioned conditions but not mentioned as supporting hypotheses may be explored in secondary analyses.

sample.value:
Ideally, we will collect observations from 200 undergraduates recruited through the University of Chicago Center for Decision Research.
Because this study has a hard deadline for data collection of March 13th, we will also collect observations from non-undergraduates. We will pause data collection on March 13th regardless of the number of observations we have collected.

analyses.value:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)The proportions of subjects who prefer the complex information display (both before and after the selection task).
2) The proportions of subjects who successfully choose the lowest-fee/ lowest-sum option in the choice task.
3) Whether any attitudinal measures are correlated with choices. 

We will also use a McNemar test (paired differences in proportions) to identify any changes in preferences from the first to the second elicitation, as well as paired t-tests to measure changes in attitudes.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

dependent.value:
Preference: Participants will indicate whether they prefer information displayed in a relatively complex (vs. simple) way. This will be measured both before and after the selection task.

Choice in selection task: Whether or not participants successfully chose the option with the lower total.

Secondary: Perceptions of trustworthiness/ transparency in companies that display fees in more/ less detail, expectations of success in selecting lowest-fee options with different fee disclosures, confidence in having selected the lowest-fee option

conditions.value: Choice task: Subjects will be randomly assigned to complete an incentivized choice task (incentivized to pick the lowest sum total) either with two simple or with two complex options.

hypothesis.value:
H1: At least 50% of all undergraduate participants will prefer more complex to simpler price disclosures.
However, even if 20% of people prefer the complex disclosure, there likely exists a market in which companies exploit this preference. 
We also intend to conduct this analysis on undergraduates primarily; however, due to timing constraints, we will be collecting data from non-undergraduates as well and may pool the data if we do not see differences. 

H2: Subjects assigned to the complex condition will be more likely to select higher-fee options than subjects assigned to the simple condition. 

H3: Subjects’ preferences will not be significantly related to their performance (selecting lower-fee options). 

H4: Subjects’ preferences will not substantially change after being tasked with selecting the lowest-fee option.
There may be a statistically significant change, but we do not predict that a majority of subjects will change their preferences after the task of selecting the lowest-fee option. 
We should note that, in a previous study that examined disclosure preference changes after a product selection task, we did not detect a statistically significant difference in preferences.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
